Ella instaló una bodega a raíz de que recibió su liquidación por el tiempo de permanencia que mantuvo en la empresa para la cual laboraba. Su situación antes de este hecho ya era preocupante por el poco dinero que recibía por las arduas horas de trabajo y su despido agudizó aún más su difícil situación económica.Siendo la única fuente vital de ingresos para mantener a su familia, cuenta con el apoyo de sus hijos que la ayudan en la atención de la bodeguita, turnándose ambos para no dejar de realizar sus tareas del colegio.Elena tiene planeado incrementar los artículos de su pequeño centro de ventas hasta llegar a convertirlo con mucho esfuerzo y a mediano plazo en un minimarket, mientras tanto tiene que satisfacer la exigente demanda de sus clientes y con este propósito recurre a vuestra generosa contribución a fin de convertir su anhelo en realidad.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to stock up her grocery store

loans.name: Saven

texts.en:
Mrs. A. Saven, 58, and her husband, Nov Pouk, have a large family. Of 13 children, only seven are still living. These are now grown and married with children of their own. Saven was a weaver when she was younger and taught two of her daughters the skill. One of these daughters, Sivon, still lives with them now, with her husband and young son. Besides weaving, Sivon also raises pigs and sells fish and bananas A. the morning market on the island. Though Pouk is now 60, he still helps to support the family doing construction work, farming and raising cows.

Saven is requesting her fourth loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $350. They will use this loan to purchase food for their pigs. Saven and Sivon are now raising 12 pigs which will be fattened to sell in five months. In the meantime, they must purchase expensive store-bought food for them. They have been running this business for the past eight years and have a buyer thA. will come to their home. Recently, some of their pigs died A. a loss of over $50 each. They hope thA. they will be able to fatten the remainder of the pigs well and make up for their loss.

loans.use: Buy food for pigs.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Mrs. Joy O. is 30 years old.  She is married, has two children, and lives in Benin City.  She sells drinks and recharge cards.   She is seeking a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more drinks and recharge cards to sell. She spent a year learning her trade before starting her business in 2007. She is a LAPO client.

loans.use: to buy more drinks and recharge cards for sale

loans.name: Chhong

texts.en: Mrs. Chhong R., 33, is married with one small child and has worked as a massage therapist since 2007. Her income averages three dollars a day. Her husband, Mr. Sam Sout, 36, works as a motor taxi driver standby at a guest house, earning around five dollars a day. She would like to use this loan to renovate their home.

loans.use: To renovate her house.

loans.name: Peourn

texts.en: Mr. Peourn P., 28, is a wedding chef who lives in Teok Nem Village. He is married (his wife is on the left in the photo) and has one child who was born 8 months ago. His wife, Saron Bor, is a factory worker in Phnom Penh, and she can earn about $2 a day. Mr. Peourn P. generates an income of about $2.50 a day in his business. He is requesting a loan of $275 to buy more timber to build a house in his village.

loans.use: To buy timber to help build a house.

loans.name: Yama De Amor Group

texts.en:
Yolanda lives in the city of San Pedro de Macoris, and is part of a bank of 20 women from her community. She has two children and in addition to caring for her household, she runs a bakery/bread shop. She wants to use this loan to buy more flour, sugar, and butter in order to always have a supply on hand. Her business has grown significantly since she took out her first loan with Esperanza six months ago, and she wants to continue expanding her business. Her favorite foods are natural juice, rice, beans, and meat. In the future Yolanda wants to continue expanding her business so that she can help other women in her community.

These six women are part of a larger Bank of Hope, and they have grown very close over the course of their first loan. They are all excited for the opportunity to take out a second loan, and appreciate the support from Kiva lenders. On behalf of everyone, we want to thank you for your support and encouragement!

About Group Loans: In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: To buy more flour, sugar, and butter for her bread shop.

loans.name: Pepetua's Leaf Group

texts.en:
Pepetua is a married woman with 2 children, ages 15 and 7 years old. Pepetua owns a small flock of chickens, which she started in 2001. Every day, she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more chickens for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Natalina, Salome and Rispa, who have livestock businesses, and sell vegetables and milk.

loans.use: To buy more chicken for her business.

loans.name: Salote

texts.en:
Salote S., 59, is married with 5 children. She has 5 years' experience in the grocery business. She sells to the village people and general public 7 days per week.

Salote has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (about US$ 125). SPBD loans are Salote’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Education and home improvement and also her church activities are important to her.

Her husband used to be a successful businessman and he originally started the business. Her kids help her with a lot of the hard work. Her children who live overseas also send money and supplies for the business.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of rice, flour, sugar, salt, snacks, canned food,  etc.

loans.name: Meleseke

texts.en:
Meleseke T., 47, is married with four children and lives in Matafaa, Samoa. She has been growing giant taro (taro taamu) and bananas for three years. She sells her crop to the villagers and the general public 2 days per week.

Meleseke has a previous loan with SPBD and will use this loan to purchase agricultural chemicals and pesticides. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (~$62US). SPBD loans are Meleseke’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Meleseke would like to buy agricultural chemicals and pesticides for her taro and banana crops.

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en: Married with two children, Habiba is a twenty-six-year-old trader. She trades in maize and beans. She has been trading for the past ten years and has since been a good resource for her family. She wants to use the loan to buy a larger supply of maize and beans to serve her customers throughout the season, especially in the face of increasing prices due to the current food crisis in her country. She is a member of the trust group called Nyame yie. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral and provide support for each other to repay their loans.

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of maize and beans.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana was born in 1972 and she is from the town of Doboj. She has two children, 5 and 14 years old. Her husband works as a bus driver and his salary is 600 KM. Ana works in a fast food place and she earns 350 KM monthly.

Ana will use this loan in the amount of 1 000 KM to buy flower seeds, because she already has a small place where she plants flowers and after some time she sells seedlings. That is a good way to earn additional money and it makes her happy to work with flowers. This job is a pleasure for her, especially after a hard working day.

loans.use: To buy flower seeds

loans.name: Precious

texts.en:
Prescious O. is 32 years old, married and has one child.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.

In her store, Precious sells provisions, foodstuffs, and tailoring materials.  She needs a loan of $350 to buy more food products such as yams, oil, beans and rice.  She hopes to retain her customers by stocking what they need.  Through her combined businesses she is able to provide for her family's upkeep. 

Precious says thank you to all KIVA lenders and LAPO Microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther D. L. C. J. is a member of the community bank Llapanchik, which means “everyone together” in Quechua, one of the official languages of Peru. Esther is a single mother with two adult children who are both studying at the university. Esther has her own business selling cereals and grains at the local market on Jirón Chorro in Ayacucho.

With her loan of 1000 soles she will invest in her business by purchasing wheat, cheese, and meat to sell. Currently, Esther’s dream is to put a roof on her house so she can open a store insiD. her house instead of taking her products to the fair each day.

loans.use: purchasing wheat, cheese, and meat to sell

loans.name: Cintia Elizabeth

texts.es:
La microempresaria Cintia Elizabeth C. H. tiene 45 años de edad, es de la etnia creole, es casada tiene 3 hijos los cuales estudian en nivel primaria y secundaria. Esta señora se dedica desde hace varios años a vender de manera ambulante los siguientes productos: picos, pati, queque de quequisque entre otros, los cuales son bastante consumidos por la población Blufileña.

Esta actividad la realiza visitando los diferentes barrios de esta ciudad teniendo como principales clientes los funcionarios de las distintas oficinas públicas y privadas. Sin embargo por las constantes alzas que se presentan en los productos que utiliza como materia prima hace que cada día la ganancia sea menos y que tenga por optar o por subirle de precio o por hacerlo mas pequeño lo que obviamente crea inconformidad en sus clientes.

Por lo planteado requiere comprar sus productos en volúmenes para poderlos obtener a menor costo y por un tiempo prudente que afecte menos el problema de las alzas.

Esta solicitando para comprar 2 quintales de azúcar a US$ 30 dólares cada quintal, 2 quintales de harina a US$ 50 dólares cada quintal, 2 cajas de mantequilla a US$ 25 dólares cada caja, 2 cajas de manteca a US$ 30 dólares cada caja, 1 bidón de aceite a US$ 35 dólares el bidón, 10 sacos de carbón a US$ 3 dólares cada saco, 2 cajas de levadura a US$ 35 dólares cada caja, 100 unidades de cocos  a US$ 0.20 dólares cada coco y  1 fogonero a US$ 20 cada uno.
texts.en:
Businesswoman Cintia Elizabeth C. H. is 45 years old and a single mother. She is of Creole background and has two children who are both students. For several years she has been a street seller of various baked goods that are very popular amongst the population of Blufileña. She visits several neighbourhoods to sell the pastries. Her main customers are the various public and private office workers. However, because of the constantly rising cost of the basic ingredients, her profit is falling and she has to choose between raising the prices or making the baked goods smaller in size—neither of which will please her customers. For these reasons Cintia wants to buy ingredients in large quantities so she can obtain them at a cheaper cost which will lessen the effect of rising prices. She is asking for a loan to buy 2 quintals (one quintal is 46kg) of sugar at US$30 per quintal, 2 quintals of flour at US$50 per quintal, 2 cases of butter at US$25 per case, 2 cases of shortening at US$30 per case, 1 drum of oil at US$35 per drum, 10 sacks of charcoal at US$3 per sack, 2 cases of yeast at US$35 per case, 100 coconuts at US$0.20 per coconut, and an industrial stove costing US$20.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy baking ingredients

loans.name: Cristales Preciosos Group

texts.es:
hola nosotros somos el grupo Cristales Preciosos vivimos en Ojo de Agua, Yuscaran, departamento de EL Paraiso, todos somos muy unidos y tenemos mucho tiempo de conocernos, nuestro grupo se forma de la siguiente manera:
Mercedes H.: soy la cordinadora del grupo tengo mas de 4 años de dedicarme a la venta de cafe por tazas y a la venta de tortillas de maiz, mis clientes son las personas viajeras en especial los volqueteros que halan arena del rio, soy casada y tengo 3 hijos, gracias a este negocio le ayudo a mi esposo para los gastos del hogar.
Leonarda C.: ella se dedica a la elaboracion y venta de pan, actividad que realiza en su casa de habitacion y tambien lo reparte en diferentes negocios cercanos de su hogar, actualmente ella elabora golosinas y vende refrescos esto es para generar mas ganancias y asi poder ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos del hogar.
Alba R.: ella se dedica a la venta de tortillas de maiz y tambien a la venta de granos basicos, ella es madre de 5 hijos, debido a los gastos de su hogar ella se vio en la necesidad de poner su propio negocio para poder ayudarle a su esposo.
Sagrario R.: ella se dedica a la venta de tortillas de maiz, ella vive con su esposo y tien un hijo, su esposo es maestro de construccion.
Berta R.: ella se dedica a la venta de articulos plasticos, antes vendia este mismo producto pero con comisiones ahora ella ya tiene su propio negocio y desea invertirle dinero para salir adelante.
todas necesitamos de este credito para salir adelante con nuestras familias.
texts.en:
Hi. We are the Cristales Preciosos ["Pretty Crystals"] group. We live in Ojo de Agua in the Honduran "departamento" of El Paraiso. We are all very close and we've known each other for many years. Our group includes:

Mercedes H.: I am the group's coordinator. I have operated a business for more than 4 years, selling coffee by the cup and corn tortillas. My customers are generally people passing through town, largely drivers of the dump trucks who haul sand from the river. I'm married and have 3 children. Thanks to this business, I'm able to help my husband with everyday expenses.

Leonarda C.: She earns a living making and selling bread, making the bread at home and delivering it to businesses in the area for sale to their customers. She's now making sweets and selling cold drinks to generate extra income so that she can help her husband with household expenses.

Alba R.: She sells corn tortillas along with basic grain products. She is the mother of 5 children. Because running a household is expensive, she decided to set up her own business to help her husband pay the bills.

Sagrario R.: She sells corn tortillas. She lives with her husand and has one son. Her husband is a construction foreman.

Berta R.: She sells plastic items. She used to sell the same products on commission but now she has her own business and wants to invest cash in improving it.

We all need this loan to help our families get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

loans.name: Takhmina

texts.en: Takhmina K. is 33 years old and is married with three children. Since she has lived with her husband, she has bought and sold cattle. She has engaged in this business for the last five years. Now Takhmina wants to expand her business and as her children are growing up she thinks that she will be able to sell more cattle with their help. She is requesting 1200 USD for the term of 15 months in order to purchase two more calves. Takhmina expresses her gratitude to everyone supporting her and promises to repay the loan in time.

loans.use: Purchase two calves

loans.name: Cledy Pilar

texts.es:
Cledy es socia del Banco Comunal Corrí Ayllu que significa Familia de Oro en quechua.
Cledy es casada, tiene 18 años y esta embarazada de su primer hijo, Cledy es panificadora, se dedica a la elaboración de todo tipos de panes los cuales son horneados en el horno de sus padres.
Cledy necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de harina por sacos.
Los sueños de Cledy son tener una tienda de ropa, ampliar su panadería y construir su casa.
texts.en:
Cledy is a partner of Banco Comunal Corri Ayllu which means “Golden Family” in Quechua language. Cledy is married; she is 18 and pregnant with her first child. She is a baker; she elaborates all kinds of bread which are baked in her parents’ oven. Cledy needs a loan of 1,600 soles which will be invested in purchasing sacks of flour. Cledy’s dreams are to have an apparel store, expand the bakery and build a house.


Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Martinez Cairo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy flour sacks

loans.name: Jose Ernesto

texts.es: Don José tiene 52 años de edad, reside en laureles norte, sus hijos son independientes, su negocio es juegos mecánicos lo cual anda en departamento oh por todo el país, que andan recorriendo las fiestas patronales. Tiene veinticinco años que heredo de sus padres, el cual era su sustento para su familia,  esta es su quinta solicitud en Afodenic que es de mucho beneficios para la inversión de su negocio con este crédito va a comprar dos juegos mecánicos.  Sus planes es poder cambiar de motor a los juegos como pintar todos lo juegos para brindar un mejor servicios a sus clientes y seguir con la tradición y trabajo de su negocio.
texts.en:
José is 52 years old and lives in Laureles Norte. His children are independent. His business is mechanical toys, which can be found in his department and throughout the country, and during various celebrations. He inherited this from his parents 25 years ago, and it has provided a livelihood for his family. This is his fifth loan from Afodenic, whose investment has been very beneficial to his business. He will use this loan to purchase mechanical toys. He plans to change the toys' motors and paint them all, providing better service to his customers and continuing the tradition of his business.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase mechanical toys

loans.name: Silvia Adriana

texts.es: La sra. Silvia se dedica a la venta de cosméticos por catálogo, trabaja desde hace tiempo en la institución, vive con su esposo y con sus dos hijos en edad escolar, ella ayuda con los gastos de la casa con esta actividad. Vende sus productos por la zona y a las sras. del colegio de sus hijos. Es una cliente muy responsable, invertirá el crédito en la compra de productos para el día del padre.
texts.en:
Silvia dedicates herself to cosmetics catalog sales, having worked with the institution for some time. She lives with her husband and two school-aged children. Through her enterprise, she helps pay for the household expenses. She sells her products throughout the zone, and to the women from her children’s school. She is a very responsible client, and will invest the loan into buying products for Father’s Day.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase perfumes and colognes for Father's Day.

loans.name: Abdukahor

texts.en:
H. Abdukahor is a farmer. He grows potatoes and other vegetables to support his family. He is 25 years old and has three children. He is worried about getting money to sustain his 2-hectare farm business. His wife supports him in all his decisions. Together, they work hard to raise their children well. He has been tilling the land for four years.

Abdukahor is asking a loan of $1000 USD that he will use to buy more seed and fertilizer. The loan will allow him to have an abundant harvest.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and for it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after Tajikistan’s independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seed and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Rebeca has a bean shop in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She currently earns very little monthly profit. Each day, she works at her business for twelve hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more beans for resale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Rebeca is a 45 year old widow with two children, who are ages 19 and 17. She also cares for two additional dependents. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member Nibonisye, who owns her own small business selling rice in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more beans for resale.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.ru: Ахмад- молодой человек, 24 лет, женат имеет одного ребёнка.Занимается продажей в розницу компакт дисками и видеокассетами.Его точка реализации расположена на рынке города Худжанда.Он имеет большой ассортимент дисков на просмотр населению.На увеличение оборотного капитала, компакт дисков он решил взять кредит. Ему посоветовал его близкий друг , который уже несколько раз берёт у нас кредит.Ахмад ознакомившись с программой фонда решил попробовать в кредит расширить свой бизнес.Ему нравятся все условия Микроинвеста.Ахмад на снимке в день мониторинга на месте своего бизнеса.
texts.en:
Ahmad is a young man of 24, who is married and has one child. He sells CDs and DVDs retail. His sales outlet is located in the Khujand city marketplace. Ahmad has a wide assortment of discs for people to peruse. He has decided to take out a loan to increase his working capital and compact discs. A close friend, a repeat loan client of MicroInvest, advised him to do so. After acquainting himself with the financing program, Ahmad decided to try a business expansion loan, as he likes MicroInvest's terms. In the photograph, Ahmad is at his place of business on the day MicroInvest visited.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: CD and DVD sales

loans.name: Tawopaneh Multi-Purpose Group

texts.en:
This is Adama C., Salamatu G. and Hassanatu K.. They named their group “Tawopaneh Multi-Purpose”.

This is not the first loan these entrepreneurs are requesting from SMT/Kiva. Previous loans have created meaningful impact into the lives of these borrowers. Previously, each of them received a loan of Le 600,000.

Having repaid the last loan successfully, they are now requesting a new loan of Le 800,000 each to further strengthen their businesses. With this loan, they will be able to increase the size and quality of their businesses and consequently make better profit and improve on their standards of living. 

Adama C. (left) is the leader of this group. Adama is thirty-eight years of age and was born in Mabonto village, about fifteen miles from Magburaka town, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a farmer and they have seven children. Her children are still attending school: some are in primary and others in secondary school.

Adama sells bars of soap and market food. She has been a businesswoman for fifteen years.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora D. has been tilling the rice field for 37 years. She is 60 years old this year. She is already a widow and what is left to her is her six children, who are also having their own families. She has a 1 hectare rice farm. Her harvest is what she uses to support her own needs as well as those of her children.

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and other farming needs. She hopes that with her loan that she availed herself of from CEVI she will be able to improve her rice farm business.

Through CEVI, she has saved money for the rains. Aside from buying her own needs, she was able to provide the needs of her children also. CEVI helps small businesses grow. CEVI provides credit assistance, training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm needs

loans.name: Martha De

texts.es: Martha está casada y cuenta con 39 años de edad, tiene 4 hijos y vive en su domicilio que es propio y se encuentra ubicado en la comunidad. Martha se dedica a la producción y comercialización de hortalizas con experiencia de 19 años y el esposo trabaja con su propio minibús. La competencia es alta, ella tiene su propia clientela  ya que por la forma de atender  a sus clientes y principalmente la puntualidad en la entrega de productos es  de las preferidas. El destino del préstamo es para la compra de abono y reparación de carpa solar. Cuenta con buen historial crediticio.
texts.en:
Thirty-nine-year-old Martha is married and has 4 children. She lives in her own home, which is located in the community. Martha has 19 years experience in the cultivation and sale of vegetables, and her husband drives his own minibus. Faced with stiff competition, she is one of the preferred suppliers because of her attention to her customers' needs and especially because of her punctual delivery of products. This loan will be used to buy fertilizer and to repair the greenhouse. She has a good credit record.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer and repair of greenhouse

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina is 26 years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. 

Georgina is a hairdresser by profession. She has a workshop located by the roadside in her community. She has some apprentices under training. Georgina has been in business for two years and wants a loan to buy working materials such as artificial hair, lotion, pomade, creams, shampoo, etc., to be able to render quality services to her clients. She aspires to give her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy hairdressing materials

loans.name: Edward Musidia

texts.en:
Edward M. is 40 years old, married to Violet Muyuka, and they have three children. His metal shop is located in Likuyani centre in Eldoret Town. He has been in this metal business for the past seven years now.

Edward was introduced to KADET by a friend who had information about KADET. With the loan he is taking, he intends to buy more materials like metal sheets and related items for welding into windows and doors.

In future he intends to enlarge the workshop, employ other staff, and open up more branches. This will enable him to educate his children and provide basic needs and parental care to his family.

loans.use: To buy more metal sheets and related meterials for his welding workshop

loans.name: Carmen Narcisa

texts.es:
La señora Carmen V. es socia del Banco Comunal “La Unión de La Mujer,” un grupo grande de señoras que se reúnen cada 15 días en un centro educativo ubicado en el barrio de Santa Mónica, en la ciudad de Manta, en la costa ecuatoriana. Este es  un banquito bastante antiguo que ya lleva 37 ciclos de crédito con la institución.

La Sra. Carmen es socia fundadora del grupo, entonces ya lleva unos 10 años obteniendo créditos de la fundación. Su hermana mayor también es socia, y el día de la entrevista las dos estaban sentadas juntas con una de las nietas pequeñas de su hermana, Nayeli, la cual les acompañaba este día. Ellas y dos hermanos más viven en el mismo barrio Santa Mónica donde crecieron. 

Carmen tiene 52 años, es casada, y tiene 2 hijos; tenía 3 pero uno se murió. Sus dos hijos ya son mayores y están casados y tienen sus propias familias. Cuatro de sus nietos viven con ella. Ella es una señora muy alegre, chistosa y amable. Trabaja junta con su hermana, María Norma, vendiendo ropa, y también tiene un pequeño negocio en la Playa El Murciélago, donde vende bebidas gaseosas y cerveza a turistas sedientos.

Casi siempre trabaja los fines de semana en la playa, y dependiendo de la cantidad de gente que hay a veces trabaja alli durante toda la semana; lleva 3 años vendiendo en la playa, y aún más tiempo vendiendo ropa con su hermana. Venden más que nada ropa interior principalmente  ropa panameña, y regularmente trabaja en un lugar que se llama Picoazá, en Portoviejo, una ciudad que queda a 40 minutos de Manta.

La venta de ropa sube y baja según la temporada, ella dice, pero por lo general le va bien. Tiene como principio no vender en lugares desconocidos, porque la gente puede desaparecer mucho más fácilmente sin pagar, por eso no le gusta mucho vender a gente desconocida o que apenas conoce. 

La señora Carmen Narciza solicitó el crédito para invertir poco a poco  en sus negocios,  en la compra de cerveza, bebidas gaseosas  y ropa. También piensa terminar el proceso de instalar una ducha en su casa.
texts.en:
Carmen V. is a member of the “La Unión de La Mujer” Communal Bank, a large group of women that meets every 15 days at the educational center located in the Santa Mónica, in Manta city, on the coast. This is a rather well-established little bank as it is in its 37th credit cycle. Carmen is a founding member of the group and has been receiving loans for 10 years. Her older sister is also a member, and the day of the interview the two of them were seated together with one of the small grandchildren of her sister, Nayeli, who accompanied this on this day. They and two brothers live in the same Santa Mónica neighborhood where they grew up. Carmen is 52 years old, married, and has 2 children; she had 3 but one died. Her two children are grown, married, and have their own families. Four of her grandchildren live with her. She is a very happy, friendly, and good-humored woman. She works with her sister, María Norma, selling clothing, and she also has a small business on El Murciélago beach where she sells soda pop and beer to the tourists. Carmen always works on the weekends at the beach, and depending on the quantity of people present sometimes she works during the week. She has been selling at the beach for 3 years, and even longer selling clothing with her sister. They sell primarily underwear and regularly work in a location called Picoazá in Portoviejo, a city located 40 minutes from Manta city. The clothing sales rise and fall according to the season, she says, but in general sales go well. She generally doesn’t sell in unknown places, because the people can more easily disappear without paying, so she doesn’t like to sell to people she doesn’t know or hardly knows. Carmen Narciza is seeking a loan to invest little by little in her businesses, buying beer, soda pop and clothing. She also is planning to finish the installation of a shower in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing, beer, and soda pop for her busineses.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma V. A. es una señora de 60 años de edad, quien vive con su madre en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada Cuatro Bocas de Upala, localizada en la Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y leche) y agricultura.

Desde hace bastante tiempo doña Vilma  está al cuidado de su madre, dice que cuando era más joven ella podía ir a trabajar fuera de su casa, pero con el paso de los años la salud de su madre se ha ido deteriorando lo que hizo que doña Vilma dejara su trabajo. Pero ella siempre ha sido muy esforzada  y retomó un proyecto que tenía en años anteriores. Ahora doña Vilma se dedica a la plantación de Teca, es un árbol frondoso el cual tiene la capacidad de no dañarse cuando entra en contacto con metales, su madera es muy resistente al agua, lo que lo hace muy valioso para la fabricación de muebles y embarcaciones.

En estos momentos doña Vilma desea obtener un microcrédito  por ¢650,000 (seiscientos cincuenta  mil colones), para darle mantenimiento a su plantación así también comprar fertilizantes, abonos entre otros insumos necesarios para mantenerle en buen estado.

Doña Vilma es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Bansuperafe; la cual está integrada solo por mujeres ya que se especializa en apoyar a mujeres no profesionales y  jefas de hogar, es una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su tercer   préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Vilma V. A. is 60 years old, and lives with her mother in a small rural community in Costa Rica called Cuatro Bocas de Upala, in the province of Alajuela. There they are developing many activities such as trade, stockbreeding for two purposes (meat and milk), and agriculture.

For quite some time, Vilma has been taking care of her mother. She says that when she was younger, she could go to work outside of the house, but with the passing of the years, her mother´s health has been deteriorating, which made Vilma leave her job. But she has always worked very hard, and she has taken back up a project that she had years before. Now Vilma works in the Teca plantation. Teca is a lush tree that has the capacity to not be damaged when it comes into contact with metals. Its wood is very resistant to water, which makes it very valuable for making furniture and boats.

Now Vilma wants to obtain a loan for 650 colons, in order to do maintenance in her plantation, and also to buy fertilizers, and to pay for other necessary inputs to keep it in a good state.

Vilma is a member of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal Bansuperafe; which is only made up of women, and specializes in supporting non-professional women and female heads of households. It is one of the 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her third loan, and with it, she hopes to continue growing on a personal and economic level, as well as actively participate in the loan organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Maintenance and purchase of inputs for the teca plantation

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.es: La señora Feliciana se dedica ala venta de ropa  de hombre y de mujer el cual lleva hace 8 años en el comercio, tambien en su tienda vende ropa interior al por mayor y menor, vive en casa alquilada mas de 8 años, el destino del credito es para poder traer mercaderia de la ciudad de La Paz, el cual le sale mas barato comprando de ahi. Vive con sus hijos que no dependen de ella, tiene dos tiendas de ropa,que crecio con emprender y es clienta antigua.

loans.use: Capital Trabajo

loans.name: Omolola

texts.en: Omolola  is 35 years old and married with one child. She has a tailoring shop in front of her house.  She has been in the business for the past eight years.  She hopes for a loan amount of 40,000 NGN to purchase more tailoring materials to sew.  She say thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace G. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 38 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Grace owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Mary Grace has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Mary Grace joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Grace is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa is 42 years old and is a local restaurant operator. She is widowed and has four kids and all are currently in school.

Adwoa prepares and sells local food like fufu with bush meat. Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain, taken with all kinds of soup. With her tasty meals she has attracted lots of customers in the area she serves. Therefore it has become necessary to employ additional hands to assist her in her food-delivering service. That was when we visited her at her local restaurant.

Adwoa says prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her to meet her production expenditures. With the loan, she wants to purchase more raw materials like baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood to prepare her meals. She would be grateful for that assistance.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for preparing her meals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her café business.

loans.name: Francis Mvuko

texts.en: Francis Mvuko M. runs Natsa Electronics and sells speakers, televisions, radios, headsets and mobile accessories and has done walk-in repair of electronics for area residents during the last nine years.  He has one employee.  His business challenge is a lack of enough spare parts.  He plans to use the proceeds of a KES40,000 loan to buy electronics spare parts.  His goal is to become a wholesaler.  Francis is married and has two children.  He describes himself as having good public relations and friendly.

loans.use: To buy electronics spare parts.

loans.name: Meoun

texts.en: Meoun C., 25, is married and lives with three young children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. C. has a business of selling grilled eggs and is able to earn a gross income of USD 50 per day to help cover the family expenses. She always travels to the town of her province to sell her egg products. Her husband sells roast chickens in the town, earning a gross income of USD 58 per day. C. and her husband work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They would like to improve their businesses as well. As a result, C. is requesting a loan of US $500 from Kiva partner CREDIT. She wants to use the loan to purchase an ice crusher. The machine will help her make coconut juice shakes for her customers.  This will be her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To purchase an ice crusher.

loans.name: Maria Felix

texts.es:
la sra. Maria Felix S. M. tiene 41 años de edad, vive en la colonia Nueva Esperanza y se dedica a la venta de pan blanco y dulce, todos los dias se levanta muy temprano para y a comprar el pan, cargar el carro y salir a vender su producto en diferentes lugares de la ciudad de Danli. 
tiene la ayuda de su hijo para el manejo del carro.
Maria necesita el credito para comprar mas pan ya que los pedidos que tiene en estos momentos son muchos y no tiene capital para comprar mas pan.
se siente muy feliz porque todo le esta saliendo muy bien.
las ganancias las ocupa para el sustento de su hogar y su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Felix S. M. is 41 years old and lives in the Nueva Esperanza neighborhood. She works selling sweet bread and candies. Every day she wakes up early to buy the bread, load her car, and go to sell her products in different places around the city of Danli. Her son helps out by driving the car. Maria needs the loan to buy more bread because she has many orders, but does not have the money to buy sufficient bread. She feels happy because her business is going well. She uses her profits for the expenses of her home and family.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bread and candies

loans.name: Blanca Rosa

texts.es: Doña Blanca Rosa  tiene la edad de 45 años, muy dedicada a su trabajo por el cual ha salido adelante para apoyar  a su hija y mama. Pues es divorciada desde hace varios años, el cual, ha sido una pena para ella, desde entonces se ha esforzado mas para poder cubrir sus necesidades, tanto alimenticia como hacer las mejoras a su vivienda. Ella trabaja como analista de estadística, desde hace varios años, por gastos diversos no logra hacer de un solo las necesidades de mejoras de su casa, es por eso que a sido de mucho beneficios los prestamos que Afodenic ha otorgado para poder hacer los cambios, con el crédito anterior logro poner cerámica. Y con este comprara zinc, cuartones, clavos y otros para poder cambiar el techo ya que esta muy viejo y se le pasa el agua, su techo es de cielo raso el cual se le a fregado todo por la mala condición del zinc es por eso urge cambiarlo para que no se le maltrate mas su cielo raso, ya que se esfuerza mucho por esta mejoras que junto con la institución ha logrado.
texts.en:
Blanca Rosa, 45, is very dedicated to her work; this has allowed her to provide for her daughter and her mother. She has been divorced for several years, which was a shame. However, she has struggled ever since to be able to meet her needs, both food-wise and with respect to home repair. She has worked for many years as a data analyst. However, due to various unexpected expenses, she has never been able to complete her home improvements all at once. This is why Afodenic's loans have been so useful; her previous loan allowed her to install ceramic tile. This loan will be used to buy zinc metal sheeting, wood beams, nails, etc. in order to replace the roof, which is very old and leaky. Her ceilings have all been rain damaged due to the poor condition of the zinc roofing. It's urgent that she be able to replace it so that her ceiling doesn't become still more damaged because she has struggled mightily, with help from the institution, to make these improvements.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy building materials to repair her roof.

loans.name: Alusine D.'s Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are teachers from a primary school in Waterloo, a small town about 26 miles away from Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city.  This school was established in 1996. Currently, the school has 14 staff members. Out of the 14, eight have applied for a loan of SLL 5,600,000 from SMT/Kiva lenders. 

This is the first loan this school is accessing from Kiva through SMT.  School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not be able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

43-year-old Alusine D. C. is the head of this group. Alusine was born in Kambia district, northern Sierra Leone. He is single with 2 children. Alusine has applied for a loan of SLL 1,000,000 from SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo, in order to buy house-building materials like bags of cement, iron, corrugated zinc, boards, and poles. 

(Attached on the photo are some group members who were not present for the group snapshot.)

loans.use: Buy house-building materials

loans.name: Cristal Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se encuentra, en su octavo ciclo.El comité se encuentra integrada con mujeres activas y trabajadoras entre ellas esta la  Sra.Fanny R. con 52 años de edad , tiene 3 hijos, de profesión modista confecciona ropas sobre medidas , fabrica lencería finas, la venta lo realiza en locales comerciales, ademas da curso de lencería a las compañeras del comité en su casa .Es una Sra. muy activa con ganas de superarse constantemente.
Agradece por el crédito por mediante la mismo pudo adquirir los materiales de trabajo que le faltaban como telas, hilos, botones y otros accesorios.
texts.en:
This group is in their eight cycle. The group is comprised of active and hard-working women. Among them is Fanny R.. She is 52, and has three children. She is a dressmaker. She makes clothes by direct request, and she makes fine lingerie. She sells them at commercial locations. Also, she teaches a lingerie course in her house to her colleagues in her group. She is a very active lady with the continual desire to improve herself. She is grateful for the loan because she was able to use it to get work materials that she needed. She got things like fabric, thread, buttons, and other accessories.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric, thread, and buttons

loans.name: Odette

texts.fr: Née en 1968 dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin, H. Odette vit depuis 25 ans environs à Agbalilamè à sèmè-Podji. Odette est mariée à HOUNGBEMON Rémi et est mère de deux enfants, dont un est scolarisé. Odette vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Odette vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les charges familiales. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Odette vend des tissus et des dentifrices de façon ambulante. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Odette s'approvisionne. Odette exerce cette activité depuis 12 ans environs et a obtenu antérieurement deux crédits auprès de ALIDé. Odette a bien remboursé les deux crédits. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Odette sollicite auprès de ALIDé un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1968 in the Sèmè-Podji commune of Benin, Odette H. has been living for the past 25 years in the Agbalilamè area of Sèmè-Podji. She is married to Rémi HOUNGBEMON and is the mother of two children, of which one is attending school. Odette lives together with her children and husband, and assists him in dealing with family expenses. To meet her needs, Odette has been selling pieces of fabric and toothpaste as an itinerant vendor. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. She has been in this line of business for approximately 12 years and has already been granted two previous loans from ALIDé, both of which have been repaid in full. To bolster her activity and increase customer satisfaction, Odette is now requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pieces of fabric and toothpaste

loans.name: Fidel

texts.es: Fidel, de 43 años, vive en su casa propia en  compañía de su conviviente y de sus 3 menores hijos. Desde muy joven ayudaba a sus padres en el cultivo de frutos, puesto que vivía con ellos en la selva, en donde estudio agropecuaria, aprendiendo todas las técnicas necesarias para sembrar  en esa parte del Perú. Cuando formo su familia no dudo en continuar trabajando en lo que mejor sabía hacer, la agricultura, que era su pasión. Desde entonces, se dedica a la siembra de carambolas (fruto selvático, con él se preparan jugos), por lo que manifiesta que le gusta mucho este trabajo porque le genera regulares ganancias, permitiéndole mantener a su familia, además le agrada el olor que despiden los frutos. Aunque por lo general siembra solo, cuando la producción aumenta contrata algunos peones para que lo ayuden a limpiar y preparar la tierra. Es por eso que ha planeado aumentar su producción para vender en mayor cantidad y empezar a sembrar plátanos. Este es su sexto crédito con MFP, y esta muy agradecido con todas las personas que hacen posible que éste aporte le permita continuar trabajando. Tiene pensado invertir el crédito que solicita en la compra de fertilizantes para mejorar la producción de sus futuras cosechas de carambolas.
texts.en:
Fidel is 43 years old and lives in his own house together with his partner and 3 small children. Since he was very young he helped his parents to cultivate fruit, as he lived with them in the jungle where he studied agriculture, learning all the necessary techniques to grow crops in that part of Peru. When Fidel started his own family he didn't doubt to continue working in what he knew best, agriculture, which was his passion. Since then he has worked cultivating star fruit (a jungle fruit, which is used to prepare juice), and he likes this job very much as it gives him good earnings, permitting him to maintain his family. He also likes the smell that the fruit omits. Although normally he sows by himself, when the production increases Fidel contracts several workers who help him clean and prepare the soil. He has planned to increase his production to sell a greater quantity of fruit and begin sowing plantains. This is his sixth loan with MFP, and he is very thankful to all the people that made possible the support for him to continue working. He is thinking of investing this loan in purchasing fertilisers to improve the production of his future star fruit crops.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertiliser

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cosmetics.

loans.name: Elcedita

texts.en:
Elcedita L., from the village of Palutan, is a 39-year-old married mother of four school-aged children. To make a living, Elcedita plants and harvests corn for sale. Engaged in her business for over 20 years, she earns approximately 50000 PHP per harvest.

In 2009, Elcedita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 15000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise, she is requesting a new loan, her third, of 20000 PHP to be used for the same purpose. Elcedita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Romel

texts.en:
Romel R. is from the village of Brgy.Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 34 years old. Romel is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Romel plants and harvests fruits and vegetables for sale. Romel has been engaged in his business for over 9 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Romel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to pay for services to increase crop yield. Romel is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be Romel's seventh loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Rosa Ines

texts.es:
Rosa de 47 años,  vive en Duran (perímetro urbano fue originalmente irregular, con varios cerros, riachuelos y lagunas que aún se presentan como restos de una ecología en disolución).  Su esposo es chofer ellos tiene un hijo. 

Ella comenzó desde joven a trabajar como costurera, poco a poco se compro una maquina de coser para comenzar a trabajar en su casa. Por la buena decisión que tomo ahora tiene tres maquinas de coser para hacer todo tipo de ropa,  trabaja desde muy temprano hasta que termina todo los pedidos, pero para tener mas facilidad para hacer la ropa ella quiere comprar con el préstamo una maquina industrial. 

En el futuro quiere tener otro negocio como un buffet de comida.
texts.en:
Rosa is 47 years old. She lives in Duran, a suburb that once had hills, creeks and ponds that can still be seen as the remains of an dissapearing ecology. Her husband is a driver and they have a child. She started as a young woman working as a seamstress. Little by little, she bought a sewing machine to start working at home. Because of that good decision she made, she now has three sewing machines to make every type of clothing. She works from very early until she finishes all the orders. To make it easier to make the clothes, she wants to buy an industrial machine with the loan. In the future, she wants to have another business, such as a food buffett.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Industrial Sewing Machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cheese.

loans.name: Maria Angelica

texts.es:
María de 43 años, vive en la Perimetral de Guayaquil (zona periurbana, rodeada del estero de Guayaquil), tiene una tienda pequeña, afuera de su casa. 

María comenzó vendiendo comida pero como no le fue bien y decidió comprar víveres. Poco a poco con esfuerzo pudo completar dinero para comprar vitrinas y mas víveres. Ahora uno de sus hijos le ayuda atendiendo en la tienda.  Vende bebidas, enlatados etc. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar azúcar, arroz, bebidas etc. En el futuro quiere tener otro negocio como una papelería.
texts.en:
María Angelica is 43 years old, she lives in Guayaquil, near the motorway called La Perimetral (a periurban zone surrounded by the Guayaquil swamp), and she runs a small shop outside her house. María started selling meals but it didn’t turn out well for her and so she decided to buy provisions. Little by little and thanks to her efforts she was able to earn enough money to buy display cabinets and more provisions. One of her children is currently helping her running the shop, where she sells drinks, canned goods and so on. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy sugar, rice, drinks and so on. In the future she would like to run another activity, such as a stationer’s shop.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice and drinks.

loans.name: Kadia

texts.fr:
Agée de 37 ans, Madame Kadia D. est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Mamassoni, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Kadia D. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée il y a environ deux  ans à la vente des habits de friperie en provenance de la république du Ghana. Elle vend ses friperies de façon ambulante dans les quartiers de la ville où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de trois ans. Après 2 prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) avec une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Ce quatrième prêt lui permettra de se rendre elle-même au Ghana pour acheter des balles de friperies de qualités différentes (T-shirt, Chemises, porte clés, poupées, etc.) afin de les revendre avec ses enfants de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes de sa localité.
 Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 135 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadia D. is 37 years old, married, and the mother of 5 children. She lives with her husband and children in Mamassoni, a neighborhood on the outskirts of the city of Sikasso (Third Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali). After trying a number of unsuccessful ventures, Mrs. D. started selling second hand clothing from Ghana about two years ago. She sells the clothing door to door in other neighborhoods in the city, where she is highly sought after by her clients because of the quality of her goods. She joined the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance partner over three years ago. After 2 group loans with a neighborhood women's association, she is now on her 4th individual loan, and all her previous loans have been repaid. This fourth loan will allow her to go to Ghana herself to buy bales of used clothing of various types (T-shirts, shirts, key rings, dolls, etc.) so she and her children can re-sell them door to door to a clientele that is usually neighborhood women. With this loan, she hopes to earn income of 135,000 francs per month which she will use to increase her working capital, contribute to the family's expenses, and pay interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bales of used clothing..

loans.name: Mbogo Bakyara Twimukye, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Jonabu N. is the member of Mbogo Bakyara Twimukye group in Ibanda. With his main source of revenue for the past 12 years coming from the sale of food stuffs in Mbogo trading centre, Ibanda, the hardworking and patient Jonabu N. has managed to sustain his family of four children. The 49-year-old dynamic businessman has reached a point where profits accruing to his business now amount to 180,000 Ugandan shillings per a month. With steady progress in building his small enterprise, Jonabu feels that his future prospects are rising every passing day.

With this loan, Jonabu intends to buy more produce including maize, cassava, peanuts, millet, beans and rice so that he does not run short of stock and supplies. This will improve his sales revenue and enable him to maintain a self-sustaining life as he looks at educating his children so that they become important people capable of supporting themselves in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase more food produce for resale

loans.name: Lisa

texts.en:
Lisa S. is a 24-year-old married mother of one child. For the past year she has owned a business venture running bingo games. Lisa now needs a loan of 1000 talas to purchase game prizes, and she plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $163 per week) to improve/expand her enterprise.

Lisa joined SPBD in 2010, and this is her first loan. SPBD's loans are Lisa 's only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase game prizes

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda G. is from the village of Malasin, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old. Erlinda is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Erlinda sells food and other products. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to have additional inventory and working capital. This will be the first loan taken out by Erlinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To have additional inventory and working capital

location.town: Malasin, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Samvel

texts.en: Samvel M. is married with three children. The family lives in village Soflu, Syunik region, Armenia. Samvel is his family’s breadwinner. Living in a somewhat isolated region requires special effort. Samvel has a small farm. The cattle and the land cultivation bring a source of income to the family. Samvel has applied for the loan to purchase seeds for autumn sowing.

loans.use: buying seeds for autumn sowing

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
Maruja de 40 años, tiene una pequeña papelería y vende ropa. Vive en Primavera de Duran (zona periurbana, con una ecología en disolución a las afuera de Guayaquil).

Ha ella siempre le gusto ser comerciante pero no tenia los medios necesarios para serlo, con algunos ahorros y a su debido tiempo ella pudo comprar papelería y adecuar un pequeño negocio para poder mantener a sus hijos. Poco a poco fue surtiendo su negocio con las ganancia. En las mañana atiende la papelería y en la tarde recorre las casas para ofrecer ropa y así tener un ingreso adicional.  

Con el préstamo quiere comprar papelería y cuadernos para satisfacer todas las necesidades de sus clientes. En el futuro quiere tener una papelería con mucha mercedaria y ser directora de cosméticos.
texts.en:
Maruja, age 40, has a small stationery store, and she sells clothes.  She lives in Primavera de Duran (a peri-urban zone in a deteriorating ecosystem) on the outskirts of Guayaquil.

She always wanted to be a merchant, but she did not have the means to do so.  With some savings, and in time, she was able to buy stationery.  She established a small business in order to be able to support her children.  She used her earnings to little by little stock her store.  In the morning she takes care of the stationery shop, and in the afternoon she goes door to door to sell clothes.  This way she has an additional income.

She wants to use the loan to buy stationery supplies and notebooks in order to meet all of her customers’ needs.  In the future she wants to have a stationery shop with lots of merchandise.  She would also like to be head of a group of people selling cosmetics.

loans.use: Notebooks and stationery supplies

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is twenty-two years old and single. He is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya where he has been farming for five years. His mixed farm produces maize, beans, and eggs which are all sold locally. He also owns and operates a food kiosk and a butchery in the same region. 

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 30,000 KES to expand his poultry farming. The extra income from this project will enable him to expand his business. He faces the challenge of losses due to poultry diseases. He hopes to venture into dairy farming in future and expand his poultry project.

loans.use: To expand his poultry farming.

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.es:
Felicitas es socia del Bancomunal Suni, tiene 44 años, es soltera pero esta a cargo de su sobrina de 23 años quien actualmente esta estudiando, Felicitas se dedica a la venta de Verduras como son col, cebolla, lechuga, tomate estos productos los vende en el Mercado Nery García Zarate los días Jueves Viernes y Martes desde las 2 a.m hasta las 5 a.m. estos productos lo tiene que vender muy temprano ya que sus clientes son de la Selva y a esa hora hacen sus compras, ella para expender estos productos siembra y también los compra para poder revenderlo.
El préstamo que solicita lo va ha invertir en la compra de verduras.
Felicitas es socia de FINCA Perú desde el 2005 ella se siente muy agradecida ya que gracias a los préstamos, ahora es mayorista en la venta de verduras.
La dificultad  que tiene es que no tiene un carro propio para poder transportar las verduras. 
El sueño de Felicitas es poder comprar su carro para el transporte de las verduras.
texts.en:
Felicitas is a member of Bancommunal Suni.  She is 44 years old and is single, but she supports her 23 year old niece, who is currently studying.  Felicitas works selling vegetables like cabbage, onion, lettuce, tomatoes.  She sells these products in the market Nery García Zarate on Tuesdays, Fridays, and Thursdays from 2am until 5am.  She has to sell these products very early as her clients are from the jungle and this is the time they go shopping.  In order to sell these products, she grows some and also she buys some for resale.

The loan she is asking for will be invested in the purchase of vegetables.

Felicitas has been a member of FINCA Peru since 2005.  She feels very grateful that thanks to the loans she is now a wholesaler of vegetables.
The difficulty she has is that she does not have her own car to be able to transport the vegetables.  Felicitas' dream is to be able to buy her car to transport the vegetables.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables

loans.name: Esha

texts.en:
Esha is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past twelve years, she has operated a tailoring business from home; her potential customers are neighbours and passersby. In addition she operates a beauty salon which contributes to her other source of income. Esha cites seasonality as her major challenge. During the holiday season, she makes a lot of sales while during from January to June she gets low sales volume. She hopes to own a boutique in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase cloth for her tailoring business. She decided to join Yehu because of its simple procedures and requirements.

loans.use: To purchase cloth and other materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Malu

texts.en:
Malu is a married woman with nine children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

She has operated a paraffin sales business for the past five years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Malu faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to establish a filling station in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase 50 litres of paraffin for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase 50 litres of paraffin for resale.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Danaya sont mariés majoritairement  dans des ménages polygames avec en moyenne 45 ans et 5 enfants par femme. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Cinzana Gare, chef lieu d’une commune rurale dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage et de parenté. 
Les membres du groupe font le commerce de condiments (boites de concentrée de tomate, poudre de gombo et de feuilles de baobab), de pastèques, d’habits et de boissons locales. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 3ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Oumou Sidibé, qui est la présidente du groupe, est une grande vendeuse de boites de concentrées de tomate à Cinzana Gare. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 10 cartons de boites de concentrée de tomate à Koutiala en gros. Elle effectue sa vente  au comptant et à crédit, à domicile et au marché de Cinzana Gare à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes. 
Madame Oumou Sidibé espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour assurer les soins de santé des enfants. 
Elle a pour objectif à l’instar des autres membres du groupe de réinvestir dans l’activité afin d’augmenter son volume.
texts.en:
The six members of Danaya Group ("Confidence") are married women. Most of them live in polygamous households. On average, they are 45 years old and have five children. They live in the village of Cinzana Gare, the county town of a rural municipality in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They know each other through ties of marriage and kinship.

The group members trade with food condiments (cans of tomato purée, okra powder and baobab leaves), watermelons, clothes and local drinks. Faced with the need to increase their working capital, the group members decided to join the loan program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is their third cycle of solidarity loans.

Mrs Oumou Sidibé, the chairwoman of the group, is a great seller of cans of tomato purée in Cinzana Gare. She intends to use her loan to buy wholesale 10 boxes of cans of tomato purée in Koutiala. She retails them from her home or at the market in Cinzana Gare, for cash and credit, to a clientele made up mostly of women.

Mrs Oumou Sidibé expects, thanks to this loan, to make a monthly profit of 35,000 CFA francs which she will use to pay for health services for her children. Her goal, like her fellow group members' goal, is to reinvest in her activity to increase her turnover.

loans.use: To buy cans of tomato purée

loans.name: Rugiatu

texts.en: This is 40 year-old Rugiatu K.. She is married and has 6 children ages 2, 4, 6, 12, 15 and 18. In 1995, Rugiatu established her food items business where she sells ground nuts, ginger, pepper, etc. She began her business as way of improving her livelihood. Working six days a week and six hours a day, she earns about Le 550,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000 in order to purchase more assorted local food items. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 250,000. In the future, Rugiatu plans to help her husband build a house, educate their children to university level and open a shop. She is honest and hard working and thanks you for your support

loans.use: Buy more assorted stock for her business

loans.name: Asel

texts.en:
Asel K. is 37 years old, married and has three children. She has been engaged in livestock breeding since she got married and moved to her husband’s house in Bokonbaevo village. 

Asel and her husband began this business with money that they earned from selling their personal minivan because that was the only way to find means of subsistence for their family. Starting with purchasing ten sheep and one cow, she managed to develop her farm successfully and now has two milk cows and sheep. 

With the revenues from this activity, Asel was able to pay for the education of her elder daughter, Aizhamal, who is a second-year student. 

Now, in order to increase the number of her cattle, Asel is requesting a loan of 100,000 KGS to broaden her business by purchasing more cattle. With the revenues from this investment, Asel dreams to buy a plot of land and plant it with apricot. 

Asel believes that a person’s life depends on his character and she does her best to bring up her children to be purposeful and persistent persons. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors. Bai-Tushum and Partners use Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
Rano is married, has five children and makes a living by running a store in the town of Kurgantyube. Her main products are food items, tea, coffee, sweets and refrigerated beverages. She has been in this line of work for six years and is applying for this loan, for $3,000, to buy fresh groceries, which always sell well in winter. She wants to expand her store so that she can provide a better life for her family.
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being the home of a key post along the Silk Road and the place where the rule of Alexander the Great ended. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only seven percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients have viable business propositions. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell in a retail store

loans.name: Nigdalia Irela

texts.es: La señora Nigdalia Irela tiene 46 años. La señora se dedica a una pulpería. Ella empezó con este negocio desde hace dos años,  nunca pensó que se dedicaría a esta actividad algún día. Ella empezó con este negocio como una búsqueda alternativa de una fuente de ingresos que le permitiera obtener ingresos adicionales por lo que es muy importante para ella y su familia, por lo que siempre se ha esforzado por proporcionarles a sus hijos lo necesario. Actualmente solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo y comprar productos necesarios como golosinas, pan, galletas y granos básicos. Sueña con mejorar su negocio y proporcionarle los ingresos necesarios para sufragar los gastos del hogar.
texts.en: Señora Nigdalia Irela is 46 years old.  She makes her living running a general store.  She opened her business two years ago.  She never thought she'd be making her living in this way.  She began her business as she was searching for an alternative income source that would provide additional income.  The extra money is very important to her and to her family, as she has always made the effort to provide her children with whatever they need.  Currently, Señora Nigdalia is requesting the financing for working capital and to puchase some necessary products, like sweets, bread, cookies and basic grains.  She hopes to improve her business and earn enough income to defray her living expenses.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Las Reynas Triunfadoras Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “REINAS TRIUNFADORAS” iniciará un nuevo proceso más en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Los Andes.  Está compuesta por  nueve integrantes, las que están dirigidas por una mesa directiva que tiene como presidenta la señora Angélica.

La señora Angélica, indica que es el primer ciclo de trabajo de la A.C. “Reinas Triunfadoras”, y nos cuenta que antes estuvo trabajando en el centro focal de Alto Lima cuatro ciclos.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con un negocio de ropasicos (perlas en las telas); pero con el préstamo que ahora sacara piensa abrir otro negocio, el que consiste en el tejido de chambritas (chompas para bebe) y que los mismos serán vendidos en la feria 16 de julio, de la ciudad de El Alto. Esta forma de trabajo le ayudará a apoyar un poco más a su familia ya que ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.

Cuando se le consultó qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el ahorro obligatorio y que ella esta animada a seguir adelante.

Con respecto a las integrantes de la asociación, podemos decir que ellas llevan adelante  variados tipos de negocios, los que son: Tienda de barrio, tienda de abarrotes, tejido de mantas, producción de mantas, venta de dulces, venta de verduras, venta de comida, comercio de deportivos.
texts.en:
The “REINAS TRIUNFADORAS” (Triumphant Queens) communal bank will start a new process in Pro Mujer as part of the Los Andes Focal Center.  It has nine members led by a governing board chaired by the President, Angélica.  She mentions that this is her first cycle with the “Reinas Triunfadoras” communal bank but she worked four cycles in the Alto Lima Focal Center.
